andrea-bad-bunny.content: quiero a alguien que se atreva.

english.contextual: I want someone who dares.
english.literal: I want to someone that dares himself.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'se atreva' employs the subjunctive mood, which is triggered by the 'que' after 'alguien'. This construction is common when expressing desires or needs related to an indefinite person.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: cuatro de la mañana y andrea saliendo de la perla.

english.contextual: Four in the morning and Andrea leaving La Perla.
english.literal: Four of the morning and Andrea leaving from the pearl.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: muchos la critican sin conocerla.

english.contextual: Many criticize her without knowing her.
english.literal: Many her criticize without knowing her.

learningInsights.insight: The placement of 'la' before 'critican' demonstrates the use of object pronouns in Spanish. Also, using the infinitive 'conocerla' after 'sin' is a standard construction to express 'without' + gerund.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: calle como un civic, inteligente como un tesla.

english.contextual: Street smart like a Civic, intelligent like a Tesla.
english.literal: Street like a Civic, intelligent like a Tesla.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: soñando con alguien que pueda comprenderla.

english.contextual: Dreaming of someone who can understand her.
english.literal: Dreaming with someone that can understand her.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'pueda' is the subjunctive mood after 'que' when referring to an indefinite 'alguien'. This shows a common grammatical pattern when expressing desires or uncertainty about someone's ability.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y no quiera cambiarla, solo quererla.

english.contextual: and don't try to change her, just love her.
english.literal: and no want change her, only love her.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: solo quererla.

english.contextual: just love her.
english.literal: only love her.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: de la iupi para la inter, de la inter para sagrado.

english.contextual: from the UPI to the Inter, from the Inter to Sagrado.
english.literal: from the UPI to the Inter, from the Inter to Sagrado.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: equivocándose de amores en lo que llega el indicado.

english.contextual: making mistakes in love while waiting for the right one.
english.literal: making mistakes of loves in what arrives the indicated.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase "equivocándose de amores" is a common way to express making mistakes in love. Also, note the use of "en lo que" to mean "while" or "during the time that" something else happens. The word "indicado" is used as a noun here, referring to the right person.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: quiere quedarse en pr, no irse para ningún estado, pero todo se ha complicado.

english.contextual: she wants to stay in Puerto Rico, not leave for any state, but everything has become complicated.
english.literal: wants to stay in PR, not leave for any state, but everything has complicated.

learningInsights.insight: This sentence uses the reflexive verb "quedarse" to mean "to stay". Also, note the use of "para ningún estado," which literally translates to "for no state," but means "to any state." The phrase "todo se ha complicado" uses the present perfect tense to describe a recent complication.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: como si ser mujer fuera un pecado.

english.contextual: As if being a woman was a sin.
english.literal: as if being woman was a sin.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'como si' followed by the subjunctive ('fuera') is a common way to express hypothetical or counterfactual situations. This structure is crucial for expressing doubt or imagining scenarios that are not true. Also, it's worth noting that the verb 'ser' is used here to describe an inherent quality ('being a woman').

andrea-bad-bunny.content: la demonia ha despertado.

english.contextual: The she-devil has awakened.
english.literal: the she-devil has awakened.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: una guerrera.

english.contextual: A warrior.
english.literal: a warrior.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: juana de arco, temperamental, niurka marcos.

english.contextual: Joan of Arc, temperamental, Niurka Marcos.
english.literal: Joan of Arc, temperamental, Niurka Marcos.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: a la buena, beso y abrazo.

english.contextual: On the good side, a kiss and a hug.
english.literal: to the good, kiss and hug.

learningInsights.insight: The expression 'a la buena' implies a positive or amicable approach. Understanding such idiomatic phrases is important for grasping the nuances of everyday Spanish. It provides insight into cultural values of warmth and friendliness.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: a la mala, botellazo, sin soltar el vaso.

english.contextual: Dealing with things the hard way, a hit with a bottle, without letting go of the glass.
english.literal: to the bad, bottle hit, without releasing the glass.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase 'a la mala' means 'the hard way' or 'by force'. 'Sin soltar el vaso' is interesting because it implies determination even in a chaotic situation.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: le gustaba el basket, leer tú y hacerse lazos.

english.contextual: She liked basketball, reading you, and forming connections.
english.literal: to her liked the basketball, reading you and making ties.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: pero de esa niña solo quedan pedazos.

english.contextual: But of that girl, only pieces remain.
english.literal: but of that girl only remain pieces.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: se ha buscado un par de casos.

english.contextual: She has gotten herself into a couple of situations.
english.literal: she has looked for a pair of cases.

learningInsights.insight: The reflexive construction 'se ha buscado' indicates that she got herself into the situations. 'Un par de casos' is a common way to say 'a couple of situations'.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: por no aguantarle chistes a ningún payaso.

english.contextual: For not putting up with jokes from any clown.
english.literal: for not enduring jokes to any clown.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'aguantarle' (to endure it) implies tolerating something unpleasant. The construction 'a ningún payaso' emphasizes that she doesn't tolerate jokes from anyone she considers a 'clown'.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: mírala cómo camina.

english.contextual: Look at her, how she walks.
english.literal: look at her how she walks.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: lo que le falta es la tarima.

english.contextual: What she needs is the stage.
english.literal: what to her is missing is the stage.

learningInsights.insight: The structure 'lo que + verb + es' is used to emphasize what someone needs or lacks. It translates to 'what (pronoun) needs is (noun)'

andrea-bad-bunny.content: cansada de esperar propina y de lo que su familia opina.

english.contextual: Tired of waiting for tips and what her family thinks.
english.literal: tired of waiting tip and of what her family thinks.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: para colmo ahora, el gobierno la llama asesina.

english.contextual: To top it off, now the government calls her a murderer.
english.literal: for peak now, the government her calls murderer.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase 'para colmo' is an idiomatic expression that means 'to top it off' or 'to make matters worse.' It's used to indicate an additional negative event.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: una diva campesina.

english.contextual: A peasant diva.
english.literal: a diva peasant.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: chico, quédate en tu esquina y no pidas rosas si no aguantas espinas, no.

english.contextual: Boy, stay in your place and don't ask for roses if you can't handle thorns, no.
english.literal: Boy, stay in your corner and don't ask for roses if you don't endure thorns, no.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: no quiero que nadie me diga lo que yo tengo que hacer.

english.contextual: I don't want anyone telling me what I have to do.
english.literal: I don't want that nobody tells me what I have that do.

learningInsights.insight: The construction 'no quiero que + subjunctive' is used to express a desire that someone else does not do something. Also, the use of 'nadie' requires the 'que' clause to be in the subjunctive mood ('diga'). This sentence demonstrates a common way to express not wanting someone to tell you what to do.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: se ponen a hablar y conmigo verán, no van a joder.

english.contextual: They start talking and they'll see with me, they're not going to mess around.
english.literal: They start to talk and with me they will see, they are not going to bother.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase 'se ponen a + infinitive' indicates the beginning of an action ('se ponen a hablar' means 'they start talking'). The verb 'joder' is a colloquial term meaning 'to bother', 'to mess around', or 'to screw around', and its usage varies depending on the context and region.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: que digan lo que sea.

english.contextual: Let them say whatever.
english.literal: That they say what it is.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: yo subo y bajo como la marea.

english.contextual: I go up and down like the tide.
english.literal: I go up and down like the tide.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: se tratan de montar y tambalean.

english.contextual: they try to get on and they stagger.
english.literal: they try to get on and they stagger.

learningInsights.insight: The use of "tratar de" + infinitive to express "try to" or "attempt to" is a common and useful construction. Also, the verb "tambalear" (to stagger) adds to vocabulary related to movement and balance.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: quiero alguien que se atreva, que se atreva y me entienda a mí.

english.contextual: I want someone who dares, who dares and understands me.
english.literal: I want someone that dares, that dares and understands me to me.

learningInsights.insight: The subjunctive mood after "quiero alguien que..." is a key grammatical concept. Also, the emphatic use of "a mí" at the end highlights the speaker's desire to be understood, which is a common pattern in Spanish.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: una loca que no quiere un loco.

english.contextual: a crazy woman who doesn't want a crazy man.
english.literal: a crazy woman that not wants a crazy man.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: quiere vino tinto y sushi de yoko.

english.contextual: she wants red wine and Yoko's sushi.
english.literal: she wants wine red and sushi of yoko.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: días de playita, helado de coco.

english.contextual: days at the beach, coconut ice cream.
english.literal: days of little beach, ice cream of coconut.

learningInsights.insight: The use of "playita" (little beach) is a common diminutive that shows affection or informality. Understanding and using diminutives is important for natural-sounding Spanish.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: se merece tanto y recibe tan poco.

english.contextual: She deserves so much and receives so little.
english.literal: she deserves so much and receives so little.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: la mai reza por un doctor, ingeniero.

english.contextual: Her mom prays for her to be with a doctor or engineer.
english.literal: the mom prays for a doctor, engineer.

learningInsights.insight: This sentence uses 'mai' as a colloquial shortening of 'madre' (mother), common in some Spanish-speaking regions. It also shows how professions are presented as aspirations for someone, reflecting cultural values.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y ella con bichotes y raperos.

english.contextual: And she's with drug dealers and rappers.
english.literal: and she with drug dealers and rappers.

learningInsights.insight: The word 'bichotes' is slang, likely originating in Puerto Rico, referring to drug dealers or powerful figures in the underworld.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: mi prima dice que es un cuero.

english.contextual: My cousin says that she's a slut.
english.literal: my cousin says that she is a leather.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase 'ser un cuero' is an idiomatic expression that is used to describe a woman considered promiscuous or a 'slut'. This expression showcases how words can take on very different meanings depending on the context and region.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y lo que nadie sabe es que a su corazón le hace falta un suero.

english.contextual: And what nobody knows is that her heart needs some serum.
english.literal: and what nobody knows is that to her heart is missing a serum.

learningInsights.insight: The construction 'a su corazón le hace falta' demonstrates the use of the indirect object pronoun 'le' to indicate who is lacking something, which can be confusing for English speakers. It highlights a common grammatical structure in Spanish for expressing needs or deficiencies.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: chinga cabrón, se comenta.

english.contextual: Damn it, people are talking.
english.literal: fuck bastard, it is commented.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase "chinga cabrón" is a strong expression. "Se comenta" is a common way to express that something is being talked about or rumored.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y aunque la ven jangueando toda la semana, no se ve contenta, no.

english.contextual: And even though they see her partying all week, she doesn't look happy, no.
english.literal: and although they see her hanging out all the week, she not herself sees happy, no.

learningInsights.insight: "Jangueando" is a colloquial term for hanging out or partying, common in some Latin American countries. The construction "no se ve contenta" uses the reflexive pronoun "se" to indicate how she appears to others.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: lo malo siempre se sabe y lo bueno nunca se cuenta.

english.contextual: The bad is always known and the good is never told.
english.literal: the bad always is known and the good never is told.

learningInsights.insight: This sentence uses the impersonal "se" to express general truths: "se sabe" (it is known) and "se cuenta" (it is told). This is a common way to express what people generally know or do.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: joseando para la renta, llorando más de la cuenta.

english.contextual: Hustling for the rent, crying more than expected.
english.literal: hustling for the rent, crying more of the account.

learningInsights.insight: "Joseando" is slang for hustling or working hard, often in an informal setting. "Más de la cuenta" means more than expected or more than one should.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: no hay mujer sin heridas ni hombre que no mienta.

english.contextual: There is no woman without wounds, nor man who doesn't lie.
english.literal: no there is woman without wounds nor man that not lies.

learningInsights.insight: The use of "que no mienta" after "hombre" employs the subjunctive mood, which is triggered by the negative context ("no hay"). This grammatical structure is common but can be challenging for learners.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: ella no quiere una flor, solo quiere que no la marchiten.

english.contextual: She doesn't want a flower, she just wants them not to wither her.
english.literal: she no wants a flower, only wants that not her wither.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: que cuando compre pan, no le piten.

english.contextual: That when she buys bread, they don't honk at her.
english.literal: that when she buys bread, not at her honk.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'le piten' is an indirect object pronoun construction. 'Pitar' means 'to honk', and 'le' refers to 'a ella' (at her). This is a common way to express that someone is doing something *to* someone else. This is a cultural insight into street harassment.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: que no le pregunten qué hizo ayer.

english.contextual: That they don't ask her what she did yesterday.
english.literal: that not at her ask what did yesterday.

learningInsights.insight: Here, 'le pregunten' uses the subjunctive mood because it's a request or desire expressed indirectly. 'Le' again refers to 'a ella'. The construction 'qué hizo ayer' is a straightforward way to ask 'what did you do yesterday,' but the subjunctive adds a layer of politeness or indirectness.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y a un futuro lindo le inviten.

english.contextual: And that they invite her to a beautiful future.
english.literal: and to a future beautiful at her invite.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: que le den respeto y nunca se lo quiten.

english.contextual: That they give her respect and never take it away.
english.literal: that at her give respect and never it away take.

learningInsights.insight: The phrase 'que le den respeto' employs the subjunctive mood, expressing a wish or request ('that they give her respect'). 'Se lo quiten' uses both 'se' (reflexive pronoun) and 'lo' (direct object pronoun), which can be tricky. 'Quitar' means to take away, and 'se lo quiten' means 'take it away from her (permanently)'.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: que le den respeto y nunca se lo.

english.contextual: They should give her respect and never...
english.literal: that they give her respect and never it to her.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: que que le den respeto y nunca se lo quiten.

english.contextual: They should give her respect and never take it away.
english.literal: that that they give her respect and never it take away.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'se lo quiten' is an example of a pronominal verb construction, where 'se' indicates that the action of taking away ('quiten') is reflexive and affects the person being referred to. Also, note the double 'que' at the beginning, common in colloquial speech for emphasis.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: no, nunca se lo quiten.

english.contextual: No, never take it away.
english.literal: no, never it take away.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: porque ella es jefa, patrona.

english.contextual: Because she is a boss, a leader.
english.literal: because she is boss, leader.

learningInsights.insight: 'Patrona' extends beyond 'boss'; it also implies leadership and a position of authority, reflecting a cultural understanding of respect and power.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y aunque casi, casi por dentro se desmorona.

english.contextual: And even though inside she almost, almost crumbles.
english.literal: and although almost, almost inside she crumbles.

learningInsights.insight: The reflexive verb 'desmoronarse' (to crumble) combined with 'por dentro' (inside) shows how emotions are expressed using reflexive constructions in Spanish, indicating an internal process. The repetition of 'casi' emphasizes the near-breaking point.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: se acicala y se ve cabrona.

english.contextual: She gets ready and looks badass.
english.literal: She grooms herself and she looks badass.

learningInsights.insight: The reflexive pronoun 'se' is used with 'acicala' (to groom oneself) and 've' (looks). 'Cabrona' is a strong, informal word that can mean 'badass' or 'bitch', its meaning depending heavily on context and tone.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: la vida va como verstappen en fórmula uno.

english.contextual: Life goes like Verstappen in Formula One.
english.literal: The life goes like Verstappen in Formula One.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y buddy baker en daytona.

english.contextual: And Buddy Baker in Daytona.
english.literal: And Buddy Baker in Daytona.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: andrea, sé tú y que se mamen un bicho las persona.

english.contextual: Andrea, be yourself and tell people to suck a dick.
english.literal: Andrea, be you and may people suck a dick.

learningInsights.insight: 'Sé tú' is the informal imperative of 'ser' (to be). 'Que se mamen un bicho' is a vulgar idiom, meaning 'they can suck a dick,' expressing strong dismissal or contempt. Note the use of 'las persona' instead of 'la gente'.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: hablan mierda y yo lo encuentro funny, funny.

english.contextual: They talk shit and I find it funny, funny.
english.literal: They speak shit and I find it funny, funny.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: sigo mis sueños y buscando ese money, que no hay money, que no hay money.

english.contextual: I'm following my dreams and looking for that money, there is no money, there is no money.
english.literal: I follow my dreams and looking for that money, that there is no money, that there is no money.

learningInsights.insight: The repetition of 'que no hay money' emphasizes the lack of money, a common theme in songs. 'Sigo mis sueños' uses 'sigo' (from 'seguir') meaning 'I follow', illustrating the use of 'seguir' with gerunds to express continuing actions.

andrea-bad-bunny.content: y yo sigo buscando ese honey, ese honey para bailar.

english.contextual: And I keep looking for that honey, that honey to dance with.
english.literal: And I keep looking for that honey, that honey for dancing.

learningInsights.insight: The use of 'honey' is an English loanword adapted into Spanish. The structure 'sigo buscando' demonstrates the use of 'seguir' to indicate a continuous action. The phrase 'para bailar' shows purpose.
